get.description:
This endpoint can be use to retrieve all the event search jobs created
by the organization of the user.

One can filter jobs given
* their author (`match[created_by]`),
* their status (`match[status]`),
* their term (`match[term]`)

Jobs can be sorted given
* the date of creation (`sort=created_at`),
* the end of execution (`sort=ended_at`),
* the start of execution (`sort=started_at`),
* the ttl of their results (`sort=results_ttl`),

The following permissions are required:
 - View connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)
 - View events (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

parameters.name: match[organization_uuid]
parameters.description: Organizations to match (separated by commas).

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: limit a number of items (allowed range is 1-100), default is 20.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: a number of items to skip, default is 0.

parameters.name: match[status]
parameters.description: Match event search jobs by their status.

parameters.name: match[created_by]
parameters.description: Match event search jobs by their author.

parameters.name: match[term]
parameters.description: Match event search jobs by their term (support joker char denoted by '*').

parameters.name: match[view_uuid]
parameters.description: The identifier of the view used to search events

parameters.name: direction
parameters.description: Direction of the sort (accepted values: 'asc', 'desc').

post.description:
Earliest time and latest time denote the UTC time boundaries of the search.
Latest time must be after the earliest time.

They accept both an absolute time or a relative time.
The absolute time must follow the ISO 8601 format such as:
* `2011-11-04`
* `2011-11-04T00:05:23`
* `2011-11-04 00:05:23.283`

Please note that microsecond precision will be ignored (digits beyond the third decimal place).

The relative time format denotes a delta with the task execution time.
It follows the format `(\+|-)(\d+)(S|M|H|D|W)` with case ignored
and accepts seconds (s), minutes (m), hours (h), days (d) and weeks (w).
Below are valid relative times:
* `+3d`: three days in the future
* `-2w`: two weeks before now
* `-7d`: seven days before now
* `now`: current time

When a new search job is executed, the job is retained in the system for
a period of time, called the `results_ttl`. The job automaticaly expires
when the `results_ttl` limit is reached. After a job expires,
all its artifacts are deleted.

The following permissions are required:
 - View connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)
 - View events (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

The following permissions are required:
 - View connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)
 - View events (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

post.description:
This endpoint can be used if you need to make a _fresh_ token for a user. A fresh token requires the user to
send its credentials (email address, password and MFA tokens).

Unlike standard login endpoint, it only returns a new access token. No refresh token is generated.

get.summary: Return all public keys used by `organizationapi` to sign JWT tokens
get.description:
All configured keys are exported in this endpoint, at this time, we only support _one_ EdDSA key and one RSA
key.

Returns:
  A JWKS (JSON Web Key Set).

post.description:
This endpoint allows to authenticate a user given its email address (identifier) and its password.

This endpoint pushes two authentication cookies:

- _Access token_, which has a short life cookie that is usable on other Analytic solution endpoints,
- _Refresh token_, which is a long life cookie that is usable only on Analytic solutions authentication API to request
  a renewed access token (via the `/auth/refresh` endpoint).

If the user that wants to log-in has enabled multi-factor authentication (MFA), then, this endpoint returns a
401 error (with the `MFA102` error code) requesting the user to complete the MFA challenge.

In order to complete the MFA challenge, the right `mfa_data` should be submitted.

post.summary: Refresh the current access token cookie
post.description:
This endpoint creates a new access token that is pushed to the end user via a cookie.

This endpoint requires to have a valid refresh token (submitted JWT token must have been created by the
authentication API and shouldnt be expired).

This endpoint revokes the current JWT tokens (either refresh token and access token).

If user isnt authenticated yet, an `AU101` error is raised.

post.summary: Switch current user to another organization
post.description:
This endpoint allows a user to switch to another organization he/she belongs to. To proceed, you have to provide
the avatar (representation of the current user in the requested organization) identifier.

This endpoint creates a brand new access token and refresh token that are pushed as cookies (more
information in the `/auth/login` endpoint).

get.description:
This endpoint checks if the submitted JWT access token was generated by Analytic solutions authentication API and is
not expired or revoked.

JWT token is retrieved either from the cookies in the request or from the `Authorization` HTTP header.

If valid, this endpoint returns the clear text representation of the token, including the `user_claims` data.
This endpoint is only available to applications.

post.description:
User that has lost his password can ask to receive a link to
reset its password even if the current password is not
known. When a user calls this endpoint, it receives a message
on his e-mail address with a link that will point to the
`reset_password` endpoint.

This endpoint must be called with a valid e-mail
address. Account associated to that e-mail should already
exist, be confirmed and not deleted. Last reset password
request should have been called more than 5 minutes ago.

If user has already enabled the multi-factor authentication,
then the current token data is required to change its password
(see the `reset_password` endpoint).

This endpoint allows a user to change its current
password. To proceed, the current password and the new
password are asked.
The new password must respect a certain complexity in order to be accepted.

post.summary: Define a new password after a reset claim
post.description:
After the user asked for a password reset using the
`/forget_password` endpoint, it receives a link which contains
a token that can be used to call this endpoint.

In order to define a new password, user should call this
endpoint with a valid reset token (received by e-mail) and
its new password. If user has enabled multi-factor
authentication, then the current token data is required to
change its password.

get.description:
Datasource identify a source of data. It's defined by the MITRE ATT&CK framework.
This paginated endpoint list all datasources. A set of filters can be
specified to focus on certain datasources.

One can filter datasources given
* the identifier of the datasource (`match[uuid]`),
* the name of the datasource (`match[name]`)

A filter parameter defines filtering on the specified `field`.
A filter parameter can be specified any number of times, where each filter instance specifies
an additional filter to be applied to the resulting data. Said another way,
all filter fields are ANDed together. Each `field` MUST NOT occur more than once in a request.

It should be noted that each `match[]` MAY contain one or more values. Multiple values are separated by a comma
(U+002C COMMA, ,) without any spaces. If multiple values are present, the match is treated as a logical OR.

The following permissions are required:
 - View connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: limit a number of items (allowed range is 1-100), default is 20.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: a number of items to skip, default is 0.

parameters.name: match[name]
parameters.description: Match datasources by their name

parameters.name: match[uuid]
parameters.description: Match datasources by their uuid

get.description:
This paginated endpoint can be used to retrieve the supported formats. A set of filters can be
specified to focus on certain formats.

One can filter connector formats given
* the name of the format (`match[name]`),
* the uuid of the format (`match[uuid]`),
* the uuid of the module (`match[module_uuid]`),
* uuid of the organization  (`match[organization_uuid]`),
* uuid of the datasource (`match[datasource_uuid]`),
* name of the datasouce  (`match[datasource_name]`).
* uuid of the automation module (`match[automation_module_uuid]`), is an alias for the module_uuid.
* uuid of the automation connector (`match[automation_connector_uuid]`).


One can list only connectors updated after a certain date
by using the `updated_after` filter

One can also add a search term that will search in multiple
places for that term.

The `name` filter accepts joker denoted by char '*'.

A filter parameter defines filtering on the specified `field`.
A filter parameter can be specified any number of times, where each filter instance specifies
an additional filter to be applied to the resulting data. Said another way,
all filter fields are ANDed together. Each `field` MUST NOT occur more than once in a request.

It should be noted that each `match[]` MAY contain one or more values. Multiple values are separated by a comma
(U+002C COMMA, ,) without any spaces. If multiple values are present, the match is treated as a logical OR.

The following permissions are required:
 - View connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)
 - View events (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

post.description:
This endpoint allows to create a new connector format. This connector format will be private to the organization of the
creator.

If the request succeeds, the endpoint will return the previous information with the identifier of the format.
Otherwise, an error with a code will be returned.

The following permissions are required:
 - Manage connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

get.summary: Get the available fields leveraged by the formats
get.description:
One can filter fields given

- the name of the field (`match[name]`)
- the type of the field (`match[type]`)
- the identifier of the module (`match[module_uuid]`)

A filter parameter defines filtering on the specified field. A filter parameter can be specified any number of
times, where each filter instance specifies an additional filter to be applied to the resulting data.
Said another way, all filter fields are ANDed together. Each field MUST NOT occur more than once in a request.

It should be noted that each `match[]` MAY contain one or more values. Multiple values are separated by a comma
(U+002C COMMA, ,) without any spaces. If multiple values are present, the match is treated as a logical OR.

The `name` filter accepts joker denoted by char '*'.
The `module_uuid` filter will append custom fields, belonged to the module, to the response.

If valued to `true`, the parameter `all_fields` will append all custom fields to the response.

By default, eternal fields are returned. They can be excluded with `include_eternal` valued to `false`.

The following permissions are required:
 - View connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)
 - View events (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: limit a number of items, default is 1000.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: a number of items to skip, default is 0.

parameters.name: match[name]
parameters.description: Match fields by their name (separated by commas).

parameters.name: match[type]
parameters.description: Match fields by their type (separated by commas).

parameters.name: all_fields
parameters.description: Whether we should return all the fields or only the built-in.

parameters.name: include_eternal
parameters.description: Whether we should include the eternal fields in the results.

parameters.name: match[module_uuid]
parameters.description: Match fields by their modules. Even with this filter the native fields will be included.

get.description:
This endpoint returns the definition of the connector format.

This definition contains:
- the identifier of the format
- the name of the format
- the slug of the format
- the description of the format
- the parser that describe the steps to extract data
- the taxonomy of the parser
- the datasources of the logs
- the identifier of the module the connector format belongs to
- the identifier of the organization the connector format belongs to

If the identifier of the organization of an connector format is null, this format is not related to a organization and
is considered as public.

The following permissions are required:
 - View connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)
 - View events (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

delete.description:
This endpoint allows to delete an connector format
Only connector format related to a organization can be deleted. Public ones are immutables.

Be careful when deleting an connector format, it will impact the connectors using it and invalidate new logs (no more
detection on them).

The following permissions are required:
 - Manage connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)
 - Manage connector formats (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

put.description:
This endpoint allows to update the definition of an connector format.
Only connector format related to a organization can be updated. Public ones are immutables.

The following parameters can be update:
- the name
- the slug
- the description
- the parser
- the taxonomy
- the datasources

The modification of an connector format generate a revision. This revision will store the previous state of
the format. The revisions will shape the history of the format and allow to compare its evolution.

The following permissions are required:
 - Manage connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)
 - Manage connector formats (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

get.description:
This endpoint returns the documentation of the connector format. This documentation aims to help the user to
set up its appliances to forward logs and to understand the purpose of the format.

The documentation is only accessible if the user can access the connector format.

The following permissions are required:
 - View connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

delete.summary: Delete the documentation of the connector format
delete.description:
This endpoint allows to delete the documentation associated to an connector format.
As the documentation aims to help the user to set up its appliances to forward logs and to understand the
purpose of the format, Be careful when deleting a documentation.

Only documentation of an connector format related to a organization can be deleted. Public ones are immutables.

The following permissions are required:
 - Manage connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)
 - Manage connector formats (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

post.summary: Sets the documentation of the connector format
post.description:
This endpoint allows to update the documentation of an connector format.
As the documentation aims to help the user to set up its appliances to forward logs and to understand the
purpose of the format, be careful when updating a documentation.

Only documentation of an connector format related to a organization can be updated. Public ones are immutables.

The following permissions are required:
 - Manage connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)
 - Manage connector formats (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

post.summary: Parse a message against the format
post.description:
This endpoint allows to verify the parsing of a log against the connector format.

As response, the endpoint will return the parsed log as an ECS event.

The following permissions are required:
 - View connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

get.description:
The format picture allows to visually identify the format.

This endpoint returns the illustration associated to the format or the initial of the name of the connector
format if no illustration was associated.

The following permissions are required:
 - View connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)
 - View events (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

delete.description:
This endpoint allows to deassociate the illustration from the connector format.
In this case, the picture of the connector format become the initial of the name of the connector format.

Only picture of an connector format related to a organization can be deleted. Public ones are immutables.

The following permissions are required:
 - Manage connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

put.description:
This endpoint allows to modify the illustration associated to the format.
This illustration will be returned when the connector format will be displayed.

Only picture of an connector format related to a organization can be updated. Public ones are immutables.

The following permissions are required:
 - Manage connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)
 - Manage connector formats (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

get.summary: Get revisions of an connector format
get.description:
Revisions are versions of the connector format and are created each time the connector format is updated.
They represent the history of the connector format.

This endpoint returns the revision of the connector format and allows to compare its evolution.

The following permissions are required:
 - View connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: limit a number of items (allowed range is 1-100), default is 20.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: a number of items to skip, default is 0.

delete.description:
This endpoint allows to remove a specific revision of the connector moment from the history.

The following permissions are required:
 - Manage connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

get.summary: Get smart descriptions of a format
get.description:
This endpoint returns the smart descriptions of the connector format.
Smart-description ease the reading of events for humans and allow to expose relevant information in the event.

The smartdescription is only accessible if the user can access the connector format.

The following permissions are required:
 - View connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)
 - View events (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

delete.summary: Delete the smart descriptions of the connector format

Only smart descriptions of an connector format related to a organization can be deleted. Public ones are immutables.

The following permissions are required:
 - Manage connectors (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

Only smart descriptions of an connector format related to a organization can be updated. Public ones are immutables.

 - Manage connector formats (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

patch.summary: Triggers a status update on a list of alerts
patch.description:
This endpoint performs an action on selected alerts and changes theirs statuses according to the performed
action and the workflow.

The list of selected alerts, on which the action will be performed,
is specified with the filter (url parameter)
`match[uuid]`, that accept a list of identifiers (or short_id) of alerts separated by commas, while the
identifier of the action is set in the body of the request as a json dictionary.

The identifier of the action is brought from the workflow (GET request on this endpoint).

The following permissions are required:
 - Update alert status (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

match[uuid].description: Match alerts by their identifier (uuid or short_id; separated by commas).

action_uuid.description: UUID of the action to trigger, or the status to set

comment.description: a comment to describe why the alert status has changed

This paginated endpoint iterates on all the available statuses of an alert.
A status has a unique `uuid`, a `name` and a `description`.

Below is an example of an alert status:

    {
      'uuid': '00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444',
      'name': 'Pending',
      'description': 'The alert is waiting for an action'
    }

The following permissions are required:
 - View alerts (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

get.description:
This paginated endpoint iterates on observed alert types and their categories.
An alert type has a value and a category. It should be noted, that different alert types
can share the same category while it exists only one alert type with the same value and category.

Below is an example of an alert type:

    { 'category': 'abusive-usage', 'value': 'bandwidth-upload' }

The following permissions are required:
 - View alerts (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

patch.summary: Trigger an action on the alert workflow
patch.description:
This endpoint performs an action on the alert and changes the status of the alert according to the performed
action and the workflow.

The identifier of the action, sent in the body of the request as a json dictionary, is brought from the
workflow (GET request on this endpoint)

The following permissions are required:
 - Update alert status (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

action_uuid.description: UUID of the action to trigger, or the status to set

comment.description: a comment to describe why the alert status has changed

get.description:
Retrieve the number of objects of the given type in the given period
The previous period is also computed for comparison

The following permissions are required:
 - View intelligence (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

Retrieve top most used objects for the given type in the given period

The following permissions are required:
 - View intelligence (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)
 - View global platform telemetry (`00000000-1111-2222-3333-444444444444`)

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: limit a number of items (allowed range is 1-200), default is 10.

value.description:
The action step content in the case where the type requires a single string value.
 Example, for type=cisco:ios, a value might be, access-list 101 deny ip 10.0.1.0 0.0.0.255 10.0.1.0 0.0.0.255
 This property SHOULD NOT be used if object is used

object.description:
The action step content in the case where the type requires an object construct instead of a single string value. This property corresponds to an object representing  x, where x is the value specified for the type property.
If this property is used, type SHOULD be specified.
This property SHOULD NOT be used if value is used
